atDirectives.name: @apply
atDirectives.description: Use the @apply directive to inline any existing utility classes into your own custom CSS. This is useful when you need to write custom CSS (like to override the styles in a third-party library) but still want to work with your design tokens and use the same syntax youâ€™re used to using in your HTML.

atDirectives.name: @custom-variant
atDirectives.description: Use the @custom-variant directive to add a custom variant in your project. This lets you write utilities like `pointer-coarse:size-48` and `theme-midnight:bg-slate-900`.

atDirectives.name: @plugin
atDirectives.description: Use the @plugin directive to load a legacy JavaScript-based plugin. The @plugin directive accepts either a package name or a local path.

atDirectives.name: @reference
atDirectives.description: The `@reference` directive allows you to reference other CSS files or rules.

atDirectives.name: @source
atDirectives.description: Use the @source directive to explicitly specify source files that aren't picked up by Tailwind's automatic content detection.

atDirectives.name: @theme
atDirectives.description: Use to define special CSS variables and/or influence utility classes in a project. Theme variables are special CSS variables defined using the `@theme` directive.

atDirectives.name: @utility
atDirectives.description: Use the `@utility` directive to add custom utilities to your project that work with variants like `hover`, `focus` and `lg`.

atDirectives.name: @variant
atDirectives.description: Use the @variant directive to apply a Tailwind variant to styles in your CSS.
